div.head: “The Constellations: Northern, Some of the Zodiac, and Some of the Southern”
Title
div.p: In the earlier of two surviving fair copies, RF T70, Ruskin centered “THE CONSTELLATIONS” above the column of lines. Then, in what appears an afterthought, he added “NORTHERN” to the right in the margin, on the baseline of the main title; and then below “NORTHERN”, awkwardly in the margin to the right of the opening lines of the poem, he added “SOME OF THE ZODIAC / AND SOME OF THE SOUTHERN”. The awkwardness suggests that he extended the title as he expanded the poem, perhaps revealing one reason why he gave up on this fair copy and revised some of the lines (see Composition and Publication).

In the second surviving fair copy, in MS III, Ruskin incorporated his revisions to the first fair copy, including allowing space to center the subtitle below the main title, breaking the three lines as “THE CONSTELLATIONS / NORTHERN, SOME OF THE ZODIAC AND / SOME OF THE SOUTHERN”.
The fragment of draft of the poem, which is bound in MS IA, is untitled, since the surviving pages begin with lines from the middle of the poem.
See System of Title Citation for Works.

div.head: Genre
div.p: Catalogue poem.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: In MS IA, one item consisting of a vertically folded sheet contains untitled draft written in pencil on three sides.

A facsimile in the form of a photograph held by The Ruskin, RF T70, is the only known record of a manuscript containing a fair copy in ink, print lettering, which Ruskin revised in a cursive hand, using both pencil and ink.

Since Ruskin incorporated these revisions into a fair copy contained in MS III, as the first poem in the MS III Second Poetry Anthology, this version ranks chronologically as the second known fair copy. MS III is a Red Book, which begins with “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”.

div.head: Date
div.p: Initial composition (MS IA) and first fair copy (RF T70) sometime in the second half of 1827, probably in winter leading up to New Yearʼs 1828; revision and second fair copy (MS III) sometime after New Yearʼs 1828, probably in the first quarter of 1828.

The fair copy in MS III is undated. Its placement following the second volume of “Harry and Lucy” and before “The Sun”, both of which were completed for New Yearʼs 1828, suggests a similar period leading up to or following 1 January 1828 for “The Constellations”. Ruskin seems to set up the association in the prose section of “Harry and Lucy”, in which Harry gives Lucy a drawing of Charlesʼs Wain “as an introduction to astronomy”. Thus, Cook and Wedderburn, the editors of the Library Edition, may have been correct in listing the poem under 1827. More precisely, however, composition would have occurred in late 1827, although probably not as a New Yearʼs poem.

Cook and Wedderburn seem to intend an earlier 1827 date, associating the poem with the rough draft of “The Monastery” in MS IA, which they misdate as 1827 (Works, 2:535; and see “The Monastery”: Date). MS IA does contain rough draft of “Constellations”, but the editorsʼ grounds for associating this draft with the draft of “The Monastery” also contained therein can perhaps be neither confirmed nor denied, since a piece of that draft manuscript of “Constellations” is now very likely missing (see MS IA: Contents, b).

As internal evidence of dating, if Ruskin based portions of the poem on actual observation of the sky, the alignment of heavenly bodies described at the beginning of the poem would not have been possible in 1827, but rather would have to be moved forward to April‐May 1828, more in keeping with the occasion of John Jamesʼs birthday (see Discussion). However, to identify planetary movements accurately, Ruskin would need to have acquired sharper observational skills than simply finding Charlesʼs Wain circling the pole star.

div.head: Composition and Publication
div.p: Quoted in Ruskin, Works, 2:260 n. 1. Previously unpublished in entirety.

From surviving documents, a clear chronology is established by revisions of one document being incorporated in the next. Strikethroughs and substitutions in the MS IA pencil draft contribute to the base text of the fair copy in RF T70; and strikethroughs and substitutions in the latter are incorporated into copytext for the MS III fair copy (see Textual Glosses for the three witnesses). This genetic history tracks a similar record of Ruskin's development of the poem, "The Monastery".

div.head: MS IA Draft
div.p: The item of draft in MS IA is strikingly similar--both in its pencil cursive hand, and in the paper and size of the physical document--to the item of draft of "The Monastery" likewise bound in MS IA, “now must we leave poor martin there”, which contains lines 29–62 of book 2 of Ruskin's versification of Scott's novel, as fair-copied in MS III. As remarked in the compositional history of "The Monastery", the episode of Scott's plot narrated in this passage describes how the English Captain Stawarth Bolton offers to adopt the two sons of the Scottish widow, Elspet Glendinning--Edward, the younger, and Halbert, the elder. Because this stage of draft and fair copy are ascribed (based on physical evidence) to 1828, it is speculated that Ruskinʼs selection of this episode reflects a preoccupation with the recent adoption of his cousin, Mary Richardson, into the Herne Hill household following the death of her widowed mother, Jessie Richardson (see COMPPUB1"The Monastery: Composition and Publication--Stage One of Composition; FAMILYCONTEXT"The Monastery: Discussion--The Family Context of Composition). Ruskin cements composition of "The Constellations" onto this family drama underlying composition "The Monastery" when, in "Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2", which precedes "The Constellations" in MS III, Harry offers to give Lucy "a drawing of charles’s wain as an introduction to astronomy". Lucy assenting that "she would like it very much", Ruskin situates the avatar of his cousin in his paper world of text.

div.head: Fist Fair Copy (RF T70)
div.p: Physical similarities likewise connect the first fair copy of "The Constellations" to the fair copy of "The Monastery". The manuscript of the first fair copy--known only from a photograph, RF T70, taken for the Library Edition but unused--reveals print lettering in ink that shares eccentricities with other fair-copy manuscripts dated 1828, including "The Monastery", books 1–2, in MS III.

The treatment of text in books 1-2 of "The Monastery", as fair-copied in MS III, has more in common with "The Constellations", as fair-copied in RF T70, than it does with what immediately precedes the Scott poem in MS III--the 1827 anthology, “poetry discriptive”--or even with books 3–4 of "The Monastery", which are set apart from books 1-2 in MS III (COMPPUB1"The Monastery: Composition and Publication--Stage One of Composition). For the poems in “poetry discriptive”, Ruskin formed large, spindly characters with pen and ink, which he had learned to use recently, in April 1827. For both "The Monastery", books 1-2, and the "The Constellations", RF T70. He also largely avoided punctuation for the 1827 works, whereas he punctuates both of these fair copies of "The Constellations" and "The Monastery", he adopted a comparatively miniscule print-lettering, more like a serif book type. Perhaps also in imitation of typography, Ruskin added carefully formed punctuation marks to "The Monastery" and "The Constellations"--punctuation that is almost entirely absent from the 1827 poems. Moreover, the marks in the two later poems share a distinctive obsessiveness and eccentricity. Almost every line of books 1-2 of "The Monastery" is punctuated, regardless of need grammatically and rhetorically, and only at the ends of lines. This obsessive observance abruptly ceases at book 2, line 80, at the top of page 79. Just so, every line of the RF T70 "Constellations" is capped with a punctuation mark until line 20, where the practice stops. In most instances, the use of the punctuation marks seems arbitrary: while the full-stop periods usually make grammatical sense, the commas, colons, and (in "The Monastery) an upside-down semicolon seem interchangeable. Finally, in both fair copies, the lines are also exactingly numbered by fives on the left side of the poems. It appears as if Ruskin layered over his text with bookish characters to give the appearance of print, without entirely understanding their function--until he tired of the process.

How much time divides the closely related bookish treatments of the longer poems from the 1827 lyric-descriptive poems? Fortunately, the two longer poems can be triangulated with a third, the fair copy of “Eudosia”, which is dated by Ruskin as 28 September 1828. Here too are found the miniscule lettering, punctuation ending each line until it doesn't, line numbering on the left. Thus, these ambitious (and inevitably incomplete) projects--a versified novel, a catalogue of the constellations, "a poem on the universe"--belong to the final third of the year, following the Ruskins' aborted spring Tour of 1828, cut short by the death of Jessie Richardson, and followed by a period of mourning, and the resettlement of her children, including the adoption of Mary Richardson into the Herne Hill household.

More speculatively, one might order the three works chronologically according to skill. "Eudosia" is perhaps the earliest, since it frequently exhibits a bizarre mark made of two dots, like a colon on its side or a two-point ellipsis. This mark does not appear in "The Monastery", where all the colons are right-side up, although the semicolons are upside-down, with the comma atop the point. "The Constellations" exhibits no incorrectly formed marks, though only twenty lines carry any punctuation at all. Still, this correctness, combined with the prominence
of poetry densely at the start of the poem, but abandoned punctuation later. Since the , suggesting that Ruskin gradually lost interest in that feature of the fair copy; and in both, the punctuation is eccentric, his use of colons seeming more decorative than functional, although his rhetorical use of commas and periods seems marginally more coherent in the opening lines of the RF T70 “Constellations” as compared with the opening lines of the MS III “Monastery”. Presumably, though not certainly, Ruskin made these revisions shortly before fair—copying the revised text in MS III, perhaps in late 1827—early 1828.
In fact, the original fair copy in RF T70, and not just its revisions, may have only shortly predated the MS III version—or at least the second page of the fair copy may have been significantly closer in time to the revisions. Starting at line 53 of RF T70, the fair‐copy hand suddenly appears larger, and Ruskin abandons the line numbering in the margin—suggestions perhaps that, at this point, Ruskin may already have decided to sacrifice this fair copy to revision (see also textual note for line 54).

div.head: Print Sources
div.p: One verifiable source of Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations is revealed in his “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, where Harry offers to “give . . . [Lucy] a drawing of charlesʼs wain as an introduction to astronomy”. The drawing, which Ruskin illustrates with his own drawing in the text, reproduces a diagram in volume 2, “Of Astronomy”, of Jeremiah Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues. In Joyceʼs dialogue, the Tutor shows this diagram to his pupils, Charles and James, just as Ruskinʼs Harry presents the drawing to Lucy, as a first step in learning “‘how to distinguish the stars, and . . . call them by their proper names’”. He points out Charlesʼ Wain in the night sky, and describes the formation using the diagram—four stars forming a waggon, and three stars making the horses, all of them also forming part of a larger constellation, the Great Bear or Ursa Major. This constellation, he explains, can serve as a compass for finding oneʼs bearings at night, without the sunʼs position to define east and west. As a northern, circumpolar constellation, Charlesʼ Wain is always visible on a clear night; and as the diagram shows, it points to the North Star (i.e., Polaris) if one traces a line upward through the two stars forming the rear end of the waggon. From this first point of reference, the Tutor proceeds to instruct Charles and James in the names and locations of other stars, constellations, and planets (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Coversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, 12–18, 250 opp. [pl. 1, fig. 1]).

In Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations, this episode in Joyceʼs dialogues formed a node of interlocking texts, for in Maria Edgeworthʼs Frank: A Sequel the Engineer marks passages in the Scientific Dialogues where Frank can find information about astronomy. Frank, in turn, recalls an episode in Thomas Dayʼs History of Sandford and Merton, in which “Harry Sandford found his way out of the moor by the help of the pole star” (Edgeworth, Frank: A Sequel, 2:141, 140). In Sandford and Merton, the tutor, Mr. Barlow, cites Harryʼs story of self‐preservation as an instance of practical uses to be derived from scientific understanding, an emphasis likewise imparted but with more detailed and sophisticated scientific information by the Tutor in Scientific Dialogues.

In Sandford and Merton, Tommy ensures they can find Charlesʼ Wain again by diagramming the stars on paper, and he carries on to conceive of a celestial globe in order to map all the constellations. Mr. Barlow obliges with a paper‐covered ball on which the boys can record their own observations of the constellations. While the emphasis is on practical and scientific knowledge, Mr. Barlow also encourages appreciation of natural beauty:

Mr. Barlow. Were there no other use, I should think there would be a very great pleasure in observing such a number of glorious, glittering bodies as are now above us. We sometimes run to see a procession of coaches, or a few people in fine clothes strutting about; we admire a large room that is painted, and ornamented, and gilded: but what is there in all these things to be compared with the sight of these luminous bodies that adorn every part of the sky?
(Day, The History of Sandford and Merton, 165, and see 162–69, 187–88)

The poem “The Constellations” is Ruskinʼs answer to to putting the constellations on paper. In context of Ruskinʼs own “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, the poem, along with Harryʼs drawing, effectively forms Lucyʼs “introduction to astronomy”; and in the context of Ruskinʼs reading about astronomy, the poemʼs seemingly mechanical exercise of listing the star clusters carries out the method, recommended by Mr. Barlow, of “remembering these stars [forming Charlesʼs Wain]” so that “you may very easily observe those which are next to them, and learn their names too, till you are acquainted with the whole face of the heavens” (Day, History of Sandford and Merton, 163). Just so, in Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues, the Tutor instructs Charles and James in the names and positions of the constellations.

In his poem, Ruskin adopts the tactic of Dayʼs and Joyceʼs tutors by starting from a prominent point of reference—not, in Ruskinʼs case, a constellation, but a planet, Venus, the so‐called Morning Star and Evening Star, a wandering rather than a fixed star. In this instance, Venus is associated with the constellation Orion as these bodies fall below the horizon in the west, and then the poem re‐orients to the circumpolar constellations overhead After this, Ruskin carries on to list the formations supposedly in a sequence, the lines of the poem clicking along by repeating “next”; however, the organization, although not without logic, becomes more erratic (see Real‐life Observations).

Neither Joyceʼs nor Dayʼs books lists all the constellations named in Ruskinʼs poem. For most of the constellation names and mythological associations, he used a source that remains to be identified. In the editorial glosses to the poem, some connections are made with books known to have been owned by the family; for the present, the mythology associated with the constellations is glossed using an American text of the period, Astronomical Recreations (1824) by Green, along with modern reference works.

div.head: The Context of Astromical Practice and Instruction in Early Victorian Britain
div.p: It is possible that Ruskin produced this poem by relying entirely on print sources. Despite the simplicity and even numbingly repetitive structure of its verse catalogue of names, however, the poem prompts significant questions about the context of scientific education in which it was produced. Did Ruskin engage in actual stargazing as preparation for any part of the poem. Does the poem reflect conditions of British astronomoical practice and education in the 1820s? Evidence is limited, but the introduction to astronomy provided by Ruskin's familiar scientific dialogues by Joyce, Day, and Edgeworth could have not have sustained this poem beyond its opening dozen or so lines.

div.head: Observations Actual and Poetic
div.p: As indicated by Ruskinʼs sources, “The Constellations” is a bookish poem. Even in Ruskin's books, however, tutors begin study of astronomy by directing their pupils' attention to the evening sky. To what extent, if any, might Ruskin's composition of his poem have involved actual observation? Ruskin opens his poem by hailing Venus and Mars. Planets are not an obvious starting point for charting the constellations: tutors in Ruskinʼs books typically begin by asking pupils to find Charles's Wain. Nonetheless, Venus as the Morning Star or Evening Star and Mars as the red planet present striking objects to introduce young people to stargazing. Incidentally, the evidence might lend support to dating of the poem.

In the poem. Ruskin positions Venus specifically as the Evening Star near the constellation Orion. According to a digital‐age star chart, the Sky & Telescope Interactive Sky Chart, Venus would have been visible from London as the Evening Star, setting in the west along with Orionm during April‐June 1828. During those same months, Mars would have risen from the east, traveling "high . . . [in] the sky" a few hours after Venus had set.

This particular configuration of Venus, Mars, and Orion did not appear at any other time in 1828, and did not occur at all in 1827. Astronomically, then, the introduction aligns with the evidence in Composition and Publication supporting the year 1828 as the probable period of composition. April-May was the period when he tyically prepared poems for his father's birthday in May, thus suggesting at least an occasion as well as a terminus a quo for the start of composition on "The Constellations" (Sky & Telescope, Interactive Star Chart and Celestial Almanac, accessed 12 April 2023). This convergence of evidence enables us to imagine also that Ruskin looked up from his books to the sky for a phenomenon with which to open his poem.

Even so, that search for Orion was likely inspired by Tommy Merton, who, "looking up to the sky . . . observed so remarkable a constellation, that he . . . begged to know the name". On learning it was called Orion, he "was so delighted with the grandeur and beauty of this glorious constellation, that he could not help observing it, by intervals, all the evening; and he was surprised to see that it seemed to pass on, in a right line drawn from east to west; and that all the stars he had become acquainted with moved every night in the same direction". In the opening four lines of the poem, Ruskin echoes the alliterative modifiers with which Mr. Barlow describes the experience of gazing at the constellations: "'I should think there would be a very great pleasure in observing such a number of glorious, glittering bodies as are now above us'" (Day, The History of Sandford and Merton, 187–88, 165 [emphasis added]).

The bodies above that were visible at all times of the year to British youth were the circumpolar constellations--the "northern" constellations, as Ruskin specified among the classifications tagged onto his main title. Of the constellations named in lines 7-11 of Ruskin's poem, only Charles's Wain is mentioned by the Tutors in Day's and Joyce's dialogues. An observer in April 1828, however, could easily have followed Ruskin's cues by looking up from Orion setting in the west to trace the poem's network of constellations overhead. Locating Ursa Major (the Great Bear) in the center of the sky, the observer would find the “pointer” stars embedded in Charlesʼs Wain (which forms part of Ursa Major), using these to trace a path to the tip of Draco (the Dragon)'s tail. Following the wind of the tail toward the northeast, the observer would turn to the east to encounter Corona Borealis (the Northern Crown). Continuing to circle counter-clockwise back toward Ursa Major, the observer would have found the next named constellation in the poem, Coma Berenices (Bereniceʼs Hair).

div.head: Names versus Numbers: The Mythology of the Constellations and Modern Astronomy
div.p: Hereafter in Ruskin's poem, following the mapping of some connected circumpolar constellations, the sequence of constellations becomes more erratic, with Ruskinʼs repeated “next comes” ceasing necessarily to refer to formations that are adjacent in the dome of the sky. The poem is interested more in naming than in mapping, identifying the mythological figures, beasts, and objects associated with the constellations, although not pausing to narrate those myths. The poem becomes a catalogue, not a narrative.

Ruskinʼs engagement with the mythic names and poetic images associated with the constellations sets his poem apart from Joyceʼs dialogues on astronomy, in which the Tutor and his scholars, while ready to quote illustrative poetry, are dismissive of the mythology:

James. ‘Why are the signs of the Zodiac called by the several names of Aries, Taurus, Leo, &c. I see no likeness in the heavens to Rams, or Bulls, or Lions, which are the English words for those Latin ones”;.
Tutor. “Nor do I.”
(Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversation 4, “Of the Ephemeris”, 2:36–37).

Instead of myths, the lesson that Joyceʼs Tutor dwells on is the arbitrariness underlying the naming systems of astronomy. The imagined patterns in the sky whereby the ancients ordered and named the constellations, the Tutor emphasizes, were arbitrary constructions:

Tutor. “The ancients, that they might the better distinguish and describe the stars, with regard to their situation in the heavens, divided them into constellations, that is, systems of stars, each system consisting of such stars as were near to each other, giving them the names of such men or things, as they fancied the space which they occupied in the heavens represented”.
Charles“It is then perfectly arbitrary, that one collection is called the great bear, another the dragon; a third Hercules, and so on”.
(Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, 13–14).

The arbitrariness of naming extends beyond the ancient constellations to modern systems: “‘If you look on the [celestial] globe’”, the Tutor continues, “‘you will observe, that . . . [lesser stars] are distinguished by the different letters of the Greek alphabet’”, which are also assigned arbitrarily (Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversation 3, “Of the Fixed Stars, and Ecliptic”, 23). As a more sophisticated system, the Tutor leads his pupils from the diagram of Charlesʼs Wain to a celestial globe, which he uses to orient the constellations to the ecliptic and equator; and then he directs the boys to an ephemeris, a catalogue of star positions (Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Conversations 2–4, 12–47). Modern ephemerides were based on exacting observations and mathematical computations, which were the pride of scientifically advanced nations that produced these star catalogues. It has been argued, however, that their forbidding tables made the ephemerides a “primary culprit” in driving away public interest in astronomy, displacing the appeal to popular imagination that the stars had presented in the annual almanacs with a professionalization of the science that seemed inaccessible to omateur “sky‐loving men”, in Ruskinʼs phrase (Donnelly, “On the Boredom of Science”, 493–97).

As a less exacting task, Dayʼs Mr. Barlow contrives a paper globe on which Tommy and Harry can draw the constellations (The History of Sandford and Merton, 165, 187). Ruskin's poem perhaps works like an ersatz globe, listing constellation names in a sequence that oscillates back and forth from west to east and back again, or that possibly circles counter-clockwise--a pattern, if he intended any pattern at all, that Ruskin could have plotted only by referencing a celestial globe or illustrated star charts in a book.

At line 12, following the circumpolar constellations, the next listed constellation is Cygnus (the Swan). Assuming, for consistency's sake, the hour of Orion's setting in the west in April 1828, Cygnus would have lain on the northeast horizon, beyond Draco. Then the following item, Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart) would have directed the viewer back toward the center of the dome, within Canes Venatici (Hunting Dogs), between Ursa Major and Coma Berenices. For the next, the now obsolete constellation, Herschellʼs Telescope, one would have turned back toward the west, where it would have been rising as Orion was setting, located within Auriga (the Charioteer). The next, Equuleus (Little Horse), is found between Pegasus and Delphinus, which would have lain back toward Cygnus, rising on the northeast horizon as the evening advanced on April 28. The next named constellation, the Goose (Anser), does keep within range of Equuleus; however, to get from Goose to Hare—Anser to Lepus (hare)—again sends one in the opposite direction, to the feet of Orion.

At this point in the RF T70 draft, Ruskin originally cited Lyra (the Lyre), which he replaced with Lepus (Hare). Since Lyra is found in the same quadrant as Anser and Cygnus, by substituting Hare, which lies at Orion's feet, Ruskin maintained a pattern of back-and-forth, west-to-east and back again (or counter-clockwise circling), but in naming Hare he also dropped below the celestial equator to "some of the southern" constellations, as his title mentions. A few lines later, he will plunge into the corresponding southern constellations on the opposite side with Crux (Southern Cross). It seems to break the pattern that, intervening between these southern constellations, Ruskin lists Ursa Minor (Lesser Bear), which contains the Pole Star, but perhaps he paused midway across the sky only to rhyme hare and bear. He may also have wanted Ursa Minor to stand as a barrier between Anser, "stupid goose", and "cunning fox" (Vulpecula), which follows Ursa Minor in the list. Traditionally, Fox and Goose were treated as a single constellation, Vulpecula et Anser, with the Goose caught in the Fox's mouth (Ridpath, Star Tales, 182-83). By separating them, Ruskin characteristically avoided violence.

div.head: The Lenten Astronomy Lecture
div.p: After , Ruskin arrives at the Zodiac, as also mentioned in his title, which may hint at another context for his interest in astronomy. As a distinct activity from professional astronomy with its mathematical orientation combined with observation--the less popularly accessible approach, which Joyce's Tutor encourages over the mythological tradition--there thrived in the 1820s a popular form of astronomy education, which combined technology with art, modern science with traditional elements such as the Zodiac. The popular astronomy lecture was a theatrical entertainment, commonly known as Lenten astronomy lectures since they could be held in London theaters during the holy season, when plays were forbidden. The timing of these spectacles fits with the proposed April-June 1828 period for composition of "The Constellations", which might have been initiated by attendance at a lecture. (In 1828, Easter Day fell on 6 April. John James Ruskin's accounts for April 1828 include "Abernethys Lectrs" for 12s, but this entry probably refers to published lectures by the surgeon, John Abernethy [1764-1831]; Account Book, 6r).

The astronomy lecture circuit--originating in the late eighteenth century, becoming a craze in the 1820s, and remaining a staple of popular science instruction at least until mid-century--has been researched by Hsiang-Fu Huang, who finds that its performative and entrepreneurial aspects overlapped with the insitutional framework of lecturing that was supposedly displacing these popular forms of instruction in the 1820s (Huang, "A Shared Arena"). A target audience for the lectures included children, as Huang notes ("When Urania Meets Terpsichore", 60-61), astronomy being regarded as an uplifting area of knowledge religiously as well as scientifically. As a guidebook of London amusements solemnly assured parents about the content of Lenten astronomy lectures--even as performed by George Bartley (1784-1858), who was not a scientist but a comic actor, famed for his portrayals of Shakespeare's Falstaff--the spectacle would convey "to the minds of their children the lofty and magnificent ideas that Astronomy supplies"--namely,

Beauty, Order, and Sublimity in the Heavens, [which] appear to their expanding intellect, in all their delightful prospects; and the feelings, that will certainly influence their entrée into life, will be characterized by a marked reverence for that "Divinity which breathes within us, / And points out an after state to man". Adults, as well as children, will derive, from this exhibition, an increased perception of the power, dignity, and ubiquity, of that Being whom we ought to serve.
(Wellbeloved, London Lions for Country Cousins and Friends about Town, 4; on Bartley, see Huang, "When Urania Meets Terpsichore", 54-57)

Even as educational entertainments for children, however, the Lenten astronomy lectures were regarded with some criticism by educators, as Ruskin would have known from Maria Edgeworth's Frank. After Frank has attempted and failed on his own to construct an orrery, a model of the solar system, his parents take him and his cousin Mary to an astronomy lecture at a theater. The performance features something like the large-scale, illuminated or "transparent" stage orreries with Greek-inspired names like Eidouranion, which combined the older mechanical, three-dimensional orrery that reproduced the revolutions of the sun and planets with transparancies projected by a magic lantern (see Huang, "When Urania Meets Terpsichore", 49-51, 66 n. 23). For Edgeworth, criticism of these spectacles pertains not just to quack lecturers and creaky, dysfunctional orreries, which Huang finds in satires of the day ("When Urania Meets Terpsichore", 62-63); more fundamentally, Edgeworth points to conflicts with reformers' principles of effective pedagogy.

The theatrical spectacle is a grand but passive presentation, discouraging learning through experience and self-discovery. Even though Frank had failed to complete his own orrery because he over-reached his abilities, the stage orrery is "particularly interesting to Frank" thanks only to "the pains he had taken, and the various attempts he had made, to understand and to represent" the revolving bodies. The other "little children" in the audience went "dead asleep" and "even he", Frank, "after all his reading in Scientific Dialogues, had much difficulty sometimes in understanding both the machine and the lecturer". Edgeworth's most severe criticism is aimed at the failure to scale knowledge to the age-appropriate accessibility of young listeners. The lecturer overwhelms the audience "with a vast number of words, which" Frank "strained his attention" to understand, trusting that the lengthy explanations "were all necessary", yet "of which nearly half were nothing to the purpose" and put Mary to sleep altogether. As for the London guidebook's promise of the theatrical augmentation of Beauty, Order, and Sublimity, it is the sight of the real moon on the ride home that prompts a spontaneous reaction from Mary: "'How beautiful!' said she: 'and how—' sublime! she would have said, but she did not know the word well enough: she knew the feeling." Feelings are represented as accessible, regardless of age and learning; and despite Edgeworth's promotion of the Industrial Sublime in Harry and Lucy Concluded, here Frank responds to Mary's admiration: "How wonderful! What is the orrery compared to this, Mary! . . . How grand! how different from any thing that the most ingenious man in this world can make!" (Edgeworth, Frank: A Sequel, 2:251, 253, 255, 249, 256, 257).

The opposite effect on children was promised by promoters of astronomy as a theatrical spectacle: astronomical science in particular, it was argued, benefits by the intervention of art. According to the 1826 guidebook, astronomy lectures are the epitome science enhanced of metropolitan "improvements and amusements":

Astronomy, universally acknowledged the most sublime and interesting of those sciences which admit of popular illustration, is doubly valuable for its powerful influence and effect in the general improvement of the human mind. . . . {T}he science of astronomy is . . . the very science of which a popular display may most successfully be aided by the ornamental arts. Music, painting, sculpture, may be called in as auxiliaries, with powerful effect, and manifest benefit; a tasteful introduction of poetry may be deemed almost essential to success; and we would undertake that Urania need not disdain the co-operation of Terpsichore herself.
(Wellbeloved, London Lions for Country Cousins and Friends about Town, 3; see Huang, "When Urania Meets Terpsichore", 47)

Wellbeloved devotes two pages describing in detail how a new "hydraulic" orrery has improved on older "instruments . . . hitherto . . . constructed by a complication of wheel-work, which, although extremely ingenious, are nevertheless almost unequal to the imitation of those equable, silent, and undeviating movements, which characterize the grandest works of the Creator". Yet, despite the interest the reader is assumed to take in two close pages of technical description of how hydraulic improvements have brought the orrery closer to the operations of the Creator, the accompanying engraving sets the machine in a "design of our own"--a moonlit natural landscape like the scene that impresses Mary and Frank as tending to the disadvantage of technology (London Lions for Country Cousins and Friends about Town, 6-7).

Despite these conflicts with the Edgeworthian basis of Ruskin's education, some elements of the Lenten lectures correspond to Ruskin's poem. The lectures appear to have presented a somewhat uniform set of topics. In Edgeworth's fictional treatment, the topics resemble those listed in An Epitome of Astronomy . . . as Illustrated by the Eidouranion, a pamphlet published to accompany lectures by the Walker family, first published in 1782 and here quoted from the edition of 1812:

list.item:
Scene 1. "The Sun and Earth: with the Zodiacal Constellations" (p. 6).
"This scene is surrounded by transparent paintings of the twelve signs of the Zodiac, shewing how the Sun, or rather the Earth, enters and passes through Aries, Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, &c." (p. 8).
Scene 2. "Sun, Earth, and Moon: Phases and Eclipses" (p. 9).

Scene 3. "Theory of Tides" (p. 13)
In Frank: A Sequel, "By this time the lecturer had come to an explanation of the cause of the tides, which neither Mary nor Frank could comprehend. His father judiciously and kindly took them out to rest their attention, and refresh themselves while this lasted. They went into a cool room, where they eat oranges and biscuits, and drank lemonade, till the tides were over" (2:252).
Scene 4. "The Solar System" (p. 16), including "Four New Planets" (p. 23) and "Comets" (p. 29).

Last Scene. This final scene is not announced in the pamphlet by a separate heading, as is the case with the four preceding scenes, but embedded in a peroration on the infinitude of the universe: ". . . how in adequate must the utmost stretch of finite faculties be to represent infinity! The stars, disposed in constellations, and surrounded by concentric circles, may perhaps assist the imagination a little: The attempt in the LAST SCENE, if not admired, we hope will be forgiven. But was it possible we could actually take our flight into infinite space, or be borne on the wings of lightning, to the most distant fixed Star we can now see, even there, perhaps we should find ourselves on the confines of creation, and see as many stars before us as we left behind! For space has neither top nor bottom in it; it is a circle whose centre is every where, but whose circumference is no where!" (pp. 36-37).

div.p: According to this description, the "Last Scene", at least as delivered by the Walker family, which by 1828 had passed into the management of Deane Franklin Walker (1778-1865 [Huang, "When Urania Meets Terpsichore", 50]), the most comprehensive view of the constellations was presented as the finale. Could Ruskin have conceived of his poem as an ekphrastic version of this final, totalizing scene? Apparently, in this show, a transparency exhibited a circle of the starry night, surrounded by concentric rings to suggest infinitude. In an engraving by I. Stow (ca. 1770-1823), after E. F. Burney (1760-1848), The proscenium of the English Opera House in the Strand, (Late Lyceum.) as it appeared on the Evening of the 21st March 1817, with Walker’s Exhibition of the Eidouranion, published by Robert Wilkinson, Scene 1 represented the earth and sun by turning the orbit vertically to the audience, enclosing this revolution of the Eidouranion within a projection of an outer ring, which showed the Zodiac constellations. The Zodiac constellations were represented by their respective mythological figures. Perhaps the transparency for the Last Scene exhibited a similar ring of constellations in their mythological guise, which Ruskin in his way has reproduced.

The beginning of the poem, however, starts with a version of Scene 1 in the Walkers' exhibition--or more precisely, a portion of their Scene 4--with the rising and setting of Venus and Mars. As noted earlier, the poem is atypical of Day's and Joyce's introductions to the constellations, which begin with finding the circumpolar constellations in the sky. Ruskin incorporates that observation as the second stage of his poem. The Zodiac constellations form a distinct piece within the poem. The most significant point to draw from the context of the Lenten astronomy lectures is that Ruskin's catalogue may have attempted a sublime totality, an expression of religious awe.
